 --add-modules java.se --add-exports java.base/jdk.internal.ref=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens java.base/java.lang=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens java.base/java.nio=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens java.base/sun.nio.ch=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens java.management/sun.management=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens jdk.management/com.sun.management.internal=ALL-UNNAMED

\\
\\
_It's unknown for now if this has any implications on Confluence features or performance._

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install a vanilla instance of Confluence Data Center.
 #* It must be a version higher than 7.0.1, when [support for Java 11 was introduced|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-55438].
# Configure the node to run with Java 11 (i.e. AdoptOpenJDK 11)
# Start a Confluence node.

h3. Expected Results
Confluence starts with all required modules loaded and Hazelcast doesn't throw a warning about not being able to access some Java packages.

{code}
2020-11-12 18:31:58,355 WARN [Catalina-utility-2] [com.hazelcast.instance.HazelcastInstanceFactory] log Hazelcast is starting in a Java modular environment (Java 9 and newer) but without proper access to required Java packages. {code}

export JDK_JAVA_OPTIONS
{code}

h3. Issue Summary

Confluence uses deprecated data type for SQL Server and Azure SQL databases

* Tested in Confluence 7.4 and also 7.9
* Tested with SQL Server 2017 
* Customer also sees it in Azure SQL

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Install a Confluence vanilla instance running against SQL Server 
# Once installed, check the data type for {{BODY}} column in {{BODYCONTENT}} table 

(i) Also noticed this data type is used for {{BANDANAVALUE}} column in {{BANDANA}} table


h3. Expected Results

You'd see a data type supported by the current database version

h3. Actual Results

The data type is {{ntext}} which has been deprecated in SQL Server and will be removed soon as mentioned in this [ntext, text, and image (Transact-SQL) - SQL Server|https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/t-sql/data-types/ntext-text-and-image-transact-sql?view=sql-server-ver15] page.

{quote}
IMPORTANT! ntext, text, and image data types will be removed in a future version of SQL Server. Avoid using these data types in new development work, and plan to modify applications that currently use them. Use nvarchar(max), varchar(max), and varbinary(max) instead. 
{quote}

h3. Workaround

 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Confluence uses deprecated data type for SQL Server and Azure SQL databases

None

Team Calendars creates threads using a standard name convention.

Team Calendars creates threads with a generic name, such as {{pool-37-thread-1}}.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Confluence usage is increasing on many large enterprises.
The rate on which a page is modified has increased, as well as the complexity of these pages.

Consider a scenario on which a Confluence page is used as a dashboard, which is updated through an automation using the REST API each 10 minutes.
This means this page is placed on the indexing queue each 10 minutes, but sometimes the new content doesn't need to be searchable immediately.

On a large instance, on which a lot of content is updated/created on a high rate, changes performed by automation tools could overload the index queue.

Having the option to defer an update to be immediately reindexed could be interesting for large instances and complex use cases.


h3. Suggested Solution
It would be interesting to choose if we need to immediately reindex the changed content or if it could be indexed later.
For example, modifying a page through the REST API could provide an option to choose if the page should be reindexed at the time of this modification.

This would be interesting on the scenario where we update a page each 10 minutes, but only need to reindex it once a day.
 
h3. Workaround 
_Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available._
fields.summary: As a Confluence user I would like to make changes on a page without immediately placing it to be reindexed

h3. Issue Summary

"/json/pagechildren.action" returned status 405(Method Not Allowed) in Confluence 7.5.1.
 "/json/pagechildren.action" is used after you set showing child page links on parent pages as default when you modified page layout(see Steps to Reproduce - Step 1).

!PageLayout.png|thumbnail!
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Step 1
 Modify page layout in Confluence like below. It is enabling to showing child pages on default.

{code:java}
❯ diff -u pagelayout-default pagelayout-modified
--- pagelayout-default	2020-11-04 10:38:39.000000000 +0900
+++ pagelayout-modified	2020-11-04 10:40:20.000000000 +0900
@@ -129,7 +129,7 @@
             #parse("/com/atlassian/confluence/plugins/labels/components/labels-editor.vm")
         #end

-		#if (!$action.childrenNotShown)
+		#if ($action.childrenNotShown)
         #renderChildren()
 		#end
{code}
 # Step 2
 After the modified page layout, "N Child Pages" component is shown on the page screen. Then clicking on "N Child Pages" component, /json/pagechildren.action will be requested

h3. Expected Results

Returning status 200 "OK" from /json/pagechildren.action, and we can see child pages.
h3. Actual Results

Returning status 405 "Method Not Allowed" from /json/pagechildren.action, and we can see "Could not load child pages." on the screen.
 "Allow: GET" in the response header is also returned, HTTP method "GET" should be used.

!pagechildren-action_response.png|thumbnail!
h3. Workaround

Change request method "POST" to "GET" in client code(JavaScript) like below. After changed, restart your Confluence.
 - Target Files
 -- <install Directory>/includes/js/page-children.js
 -- <install Directory>/includes/js/page-children-min.js

page-children.js(modify page-children-min.js as well)

"I/O dispatcher 12" #94 daemon prio=5 os_prio=0 cpu=3439222.56ms elapsed=5220.64s tid=0x0000ff0e98033000 nid=0x3cf5 runnable  [0x0000ff0e98033000]

h3. Problem Definition
During a node startup on Confluence Data Center, it will run an index validation to see if it needs to be recovered (from a snapshot or from another node) or fully rebuilt (if recovering it isn't successful).

Sometimes, for maintenance purposes, you would like to restart a Confluence node with a known outdated (or corrupted) index without triggering an index recovery nor the index rebuild.

While preventing the node from running an index recovery is possible through a JVM property (see {{confluence.cluster.index.recovery.num.attempts}} in [Recognized System Properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Recognized+System+Properties]), preventing the node from starting a reindex isn't.

This is also helpful when we need to restart a node while another one is running a reindex.

h3. Suggested Solution
Make a configuration available so we can prevent a node from running a full reindex on startup.
It could be a JVM property similar to {{confluence.cluster.index.recovery.num.attempts}}.

h3. Issue Summary
When you connect Confluence to an external directory(Jira, LDAP), it will not analyze or filter the usernames that are being retrieved.

During the installation, the administrator account must be created. The 'admin' username is often used.

This can bring exploit issues as someone can create the 'admin' account externally. Confluence also binds the permissions with the username, not with the user_key.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Install Confluence and create an 'admin' account.
# Connect Confluence with Jira/Jira SD.
# Set the permissions on the "Global Permissions" page.
# Enable user signup in Jira/Jira SD.
# Create an account with the 'admin' username.
# Go back to Confluence and synchronize the external directory.

h3. Expected Results
Confluence will block the synchronization of the 'admin' or 'administrator' username.

h3. Actual Results
Confluence synchronizes the user. Due to the permissions set with the username, the user may have full access to the application.

h3. Workaround

* If it is possible to disable user signup in Jira, disable it.
* Change the username of the members of the 'confluence-administrators' group.
fields.summary: Confluence allows 'admin' username from external directories and the user can have access to sensitive data

h3. Issue Summary
The max entries of a distributed cache is reset to the default value (instead of the overridden value) if a cluster node is restarted.

The new Max Entries value.

The default Max Entries value

Shutdown all nodes in the cluster.  Then, start each node, one at a time. The modified size of the cache will be read from cache-settings-overrides.properties and will be correctly reflected in the UI.

h3. Issue Summary

When an administrator adds a new user account to Confluence from "User Management >> Add Users", the newly created account is automatically added to *"confluence-users"* group.

If "confluence-users" group is not added to Global Permissions and granted "can use" permission, newly created users will not receive an email for setting up their passwords.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Setup a mail server in Confluence
 # Remove *confluence-users* from *global permissions*
 # Go to *User Management* >> *Add Users* >> enter user details and *email address*
 # Make sure *"Send an email to the user you have just created..."* option is selected >> click *Add*
 # Newly added user does not receive an email to setup their first password

 _Note: This behavior is only observed when *"confluence-users"* is not granted "Can Use" Global permission._
h3. Expected Results

Newly added users should receive an email to setup their first password 
h3. Actual Results

Newly added users do not receive an email to setup their first password 
h3. Workaround

Add *"confluence-users"* group to global permissions and grant it "Can Use".
 If the instance uses a different default group, then that group needs to have "Can Use" permissions. Default group can be retrieved from this SQL:
{code:java}
select bandanavalue from bandana where bandanakey='atlassian.confluence.settings';
{code}

---------
Obtain a new instance of a SAXParserFactory. This static method creates a new factory instance This method uses the following ordered lookup procedure to determine the SAXParserFactory implementation class to load:
* Use the javax.xml.parsers.SAXParserFactory system property.
* Use the properties file "lib/jaxp.properties" in the JRE directory. This configuration file is in standard java.util.Properties format and contains the fully qualified name of the implementation class with the key being the system property defined above. The jaxp.properties file is read only once by the JAXP implementation and it's values are then cached for future use. If the file does not exist when the first attempt is made to read from it, no further attempts are made to check for its existence. It is not possible to change the value of any property in jaxp.properties after it has been read for the first time.
* Use the service-provider loading facilities, defined by the ServiceLoader class, to attempt to locate and load an implementation of the service using the default loading mechanism: the service-provider loading facility will use the current thread's context class loader to attempt to load the service. If the context class loader is null, the system class loader will be used.
* Otherwise the system-default implementation is returned.
Once an application has obtained a reference to a SAXParserFactory it can use the factory to configure and obtain parser instances.

If you create a blog post on a Space and use the [HTML Macro|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/html-macro-38273085.html] with {{<html></html>}} tag in the macro.

After this is created, the page that show the latest blog (Space -> Blogs link on the left panel), it will show the created HTML macro, instead of list of the latest blogs entries.

 # Create a blog post using the HTML Macro

{code:java}
<html></html>
{code}

h3. Issue Summary

Italicizing text on a page that is added as an 'includes' macro on another page causes unnecessary line breaks.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create 'Page A', add a snippet of text with italics for the middle word. e.g.
 'A _product_ name'
 # Create Page B, use an 'Includes' macro to add Page A in between other text. e.g.
 'Text [Includes Page A] Text'
 # Save and View Page B.

h3. Expected Results

Page B should show all the text (including the text from the 'Includes' macro from Page A) inline.
{quote}Text A _product_ name Text
{quote}
h3. Actual Results

Page B shows a line break for the italicized word.

!Screen Shot 2020-10-16 at 10.24.55 AM.png!
h3. Workaround

Two possible workarounds:
 - If possible, use 'Excerpt' on Page A and 'Excerpt Include' on Page B. This appears to keep the formatting even with italicized text.
 - Remove italicized text altogether on Page A _or_ italicize all the text (which does not add a line break).
fields.summary: Italicizing text on a page that is added as an 'includes' macro on another page causes unnecessary line breaks.

h3. Issue Summary

As an unlicensed user, if we try to download all attachments via the “Download All” link in the Attachments Macro, Confluence blocks the procedure with a “Not Permitted” message.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a knowledge base for Jira Servicedesk
 # Select the “All active users and customers can access the knowledge base without a Confluence space”
 # Create a new page for the knowledge base
 # Place an Attachments macro in the page
 # Create a user with Jira Servicedesk access
 # If the user base is different for Confluence and Jira, create the user in Confluence as indicated by documentation ([https://confluence.atlassian.com/servicedeskserver/knowledge-base-settings-and-permissions-956713322.html])
 # Go the page you created earlier
 # Click to “Download All”

h3. Expected Results

All the attachments are downloaded
h3. Actual Results

There is a redirect to an address that looks like this: localhost:8090/confluence/pages/downloadallattachments.action?pageid=<pageID> and there is a “Not Permitted” message shown.

The same behavior is present through the Customer portal.

!Screen Shot 2020-09-29 at 13.54.06.png|width=287,height=172!

!Screen Shot 2020-09-29 at 13.54.17.png|width=285,height=169!

!Screen Shot 2020-09-29 at 13.54.28.png|width=287,height=169!
h3. Workaround

The user can either click the attachment link in the macro and then download the file from the tab that opens up after the click or select to preview the file and then download it from there.

Enabling anonymous access and then not logging in to Confluence also works around this behavior.

!Screen Shot 2020-09-29 at 13.54.42.png|width=291,height=172!

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

A huge space migration can translate also into even greater pain - spaces can get so big that will cause attempts to do the XML export/import to crash.

For a huge space, admins have to devise their own migration tools or suffer from long and painful migration steps (long-running exports, for invalid characters in the files inside the backup zip file, long-running import, etc).
h3. Suggested Solution

Today the XML format is used for the main file (entities.xml - which can take an absurd side) and a few other files/directories and the attachments directory.

The suggestion is that this process can be refactored to bypass file sizing limitations by
 - using other formats (non-XML), easier to parse and work with (and potentially smaller in size)
 - implementing a wire migration tool that'd allow a space to be transported to another instance

Essentially the way to improve it is not the main thing - the main ask is to actually improve the space migration task to make it easier and faster for really large instance admins.
fields.summary: As an admin I want to migrate a large Confluence space to another instance without size limitations

h3. Problem
We have different dialects in English, such as the American and Brittish, which there are some words that are spelled different. However, Confluence doesn't understand that natively and you need to use *tilde (~)* for the Lucene to recognize.

h3. Suggested Solution
Confluence to recognize words spelled different, such as:
* Organize vs Organise
* Center vs Centre
* Favorite vs Favourite
* Behavior vs Behaviour

Just small examples above.

h3. Why This Is Important
Users coming from different nationalities won't need to use the fuzzy search to find the content as the one who wrote the document.

h3. Workaround
Use tilde (~) when searching for words that might have a different spelling.
fields.summary: Allow Confluence to consider alternate spellings in search. Such as: center vs centre

h3. Issue Summary

Full reindex process stores different objects in ThreadLocal, and do not release them until the whole reindexing process finishes. The larger database is, the more memory is consumed by the end of reindexing process.  
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Generate a database with at least 10M pages
 # Run jconsole and attach it to the existing Confluence process
 # Trigger full reindexing
 # Monitor memory consumption 

h3. Expected Results

Memory usage is not increasing (cache is not taken into account).
h3. Actual Results

Memory usage grows. Memory is released only when the reindex process finishes.

!image-2020-10-08-10-01-00-416.png|width=1004,height=834!

Heap dump analysis shows that 4 reindexing threads consume more that 2G of RAM (mostly by strings containing SQL queries).

!image-2020-10-08-10-28-06-565.png|width=919,height=671!

Another heap dump (for the larger instance) shows that 8Gb of RAM used by indexing threads. Memory was consumed by instances of Lucene42DocValuesProducer.
h3. Workaround

Before triggering full reindexing, allocate more memory for one node, and trigger reindexing on that node.

Run reindexing outside of peak hours.
fields.summary: Full reindexing leads to memory leak

h3. Issue Summary

Large spaces with a large set of watchers can trigger a lot of batch notification traffic that leads to significant delays in notification delivery.
 * This is the flow :
 ** every batch email notification task targets a set of recipients
 *** in the case of large space with significant number of watchers,  *ALL the space watchers*
 **  *every 10 minutes* the batch notification scheduled job kicks in
 *** it generates a set of notification tasks for each content updated
 **** in the case of large space, this is *every page/blog contributed to in the span of 10 minutes*
 **  every 10 minutes the thread pool executor schedules (enqueues) a new set of batch notification tasks
 *** it comes with *3 worker threads* by default
 *** the number of recipients per task impacts the time needed for a worker thread to free up
 *** the time for a worker thread to free up impacts the waiting time for every task sitting in the queue
 *** the order at which tasks were queued impacts when they get executed

 * So to sum up
 ** for a popular space with a lot of recipients and *without* *a limit to number of recipients per notification task*
 *** the worker threads get "greedy" tasks to process, and while that is going on, every 10 minutes a scheduled job adds more items to the task queue

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Generate some traffic on a large data set
 # Monitor the notification queue, and notice the incremental wait for email tasks in the queue.

h3. Expected Results

Notifications are sent within a reasonable timeframe that ensures the content sent is still of relevance
h3. Actual Results

Notification tasks can sit in the queue for more than a week
h3. Workaround

system properties (requires a restart)
 * we can increase the *notifications.sender.thread.count* from its default value of *3*, this will provide batch notifications with more worker threads

scheduled job
 * we can configure *Send Batched Notifications* to run at a different frequency, it is configured to run *every 10 minutes* by default
fields.summary: Batch notifications on large spaces can lead to significant delays in notification delivery

As Confluence Data Center and Server scale in environments, tuning the cache assets to scale along with them can become a daunting task for admins.

On the [Cache Statistics|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/cache-statistics-150472.html] knowledge base article, Atlassian references several ways to identify and tune caches for a more performant Confluence application, however there are a few improvements that would help larger, more active deployments as they scale.
h3. Time range for viewing cache statistics

At present, there is a 'flush' cache option for most (if not all) the application caches, and this also flushes the cache stats. However, I believe what would be beneficial here would be a way to check the cache statistics via a time range, so that the admins can compare pre and post flushing of the cache and check if the effectiveness has improved (or whichever metric you're focusing on at that time).
h4. Better cache statistics monitoring

As per CONFSERVER-12837, Atlassian states that they can't recommend cache values because the size of caches depends on a lot of external factors within the host machine and the cluster and primarily should be part of the tuning process to keep the application healthy.

However, I feel like some help here (besides a knowledge base article) can be warranted inside the UI. At the very least, a way to monitor the cache usage in the UI instead of relying on support/admins to review it during a time of crisis/instability/sluggishness. Maybe even a way to suggest values based on effectiveness over a period of time-based on some of the known configuration values. This would help admins make a decision on which caches to focus on during health checks to prevent problems before they arise.
fields.summary: Improve 'Cache Statistics' Page in the UI
